mcqs.question_text: Which of the following best describes why Agile was introduced, as recapped in the lecture? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: To address limitations of traditional Waterfall by promoting adaptability
To eliminate the need for any project planning or documentation
To enable iterative development with continuous user collaboration
To enforce a strictly defined, unchanging plan from start to finish

mcqs.question_text: Which of the following statements characterize Scrum? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: It is the most popular Agile framework focusing on short-term planning and adaptability
It is a heavy plan-driven approach with sequential phases
It thrives on continuous adaptation to frequent changes
It strictly forbids direct communication between customers and developers

mcqs.question_text: Which role in a Scrum Team is primarily responsible for maximizing the product’s value and managing the Product Backlog?

options.option_text: ScrumMaster
Product Owner
Developers
Project Manager

mcqs.question_text: Which responsibilities are typical of a ScrumMaster? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: Removing impediments and ensuring the team understands and follows Scrum practices
Owning the Product Backlog and writing user stories
Facilitating Scrum events and guiding continuous improvement
Approving every code change before it’s committed

mcqs.question_text: What is the maximum recommended size for a Scrum Development Team, as mentioned in the lecture?

options.option_text: Up to 8 members
Exactly 15 members
No limit is recommended; more is always better
Only 2 developers per product

mcqs.question_text: Which statements are true about Scrum Events? (3 correct options)

options.option_text: They create regular communication and alignment opportunities
They are optional, held only if the team wants to socialize
They include Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective
They must each last a minimum of 8 hours regardless of sprint length
They help inspect work and adapt plans as needed

mcqs.question_text: Which of the following is NOT one of the three pillars of Scrum theory?

options.option_text: Inspection
Adaptation
Transparency
Collaboration

mcqs.question_text: What are the official Scrum Artifacts mentioned in the lecture? (3 correct options)

options.option_text: Product Backlog
Sprint Backlog
Increment
Velocity Chart
Gantt Diagram

mcqs.question_text: Which statement best describes a Product Backlog?

options.option_text: A prioritized list of all desired product work, continuously refined
A daily to-do list for the developers
A formal contract describing final system requirements
A leftover set of tasks from a previous project

mcqs.question_text: Which events occur at the end of every Sprint, according to the lecture? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: Sprint Review to showcase the Increment and get stakeholder feedback
Sprint Retrospective to reflect on process improvements
A full design re-specification to rewrite all requirements
All developers go on mandatory vacation

mcqs.question_text: What is a 'Sprint' in Scrum terms?

options.option_text: A short, timeboxed period (≤ 1 month) dedicated to creating a product Increment
A 6-month phase of documentation only
A spontaneous event when the ScrumMaster is absent
A mandatory 3-year product roadmap

mcqs.question_text: Which statement is true about 'Potentially Shippable Increment' in Scrum?

options.option_text: It refers to a fully tested, working product addition that meets the Definition of Done
It means any code written during a Sprint, regardless of its quality
It cannot be shown to stakeholders until after several sprints are complete
It is a term used only during Waterfall planning phases

mcqs.question_text: Which concept measures how much work a Scrum Team completes in a Sprint?

options.option_text: Velocity
Flow Rate
Throughput Time
Kanban WIP Limit

mcqs.question_text: What do the Scrum Values (Commitment, Focus, Openness, Respect, Courage) help foster within a team? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: A constructive, collaborative culture supporting effective Scrum adoption
An environment where each individual can hide progress from teammates
Better team morale and trust in delivering increments
Complete elimination of stakeholder feedback loops

mcqs.question_text: Which of these reflect key benefits of having timeboxed sprints? (3 correct options)

options.option_text: Consistent cadence for planning, review, and feedback
Endless extension of sprints until all features are done
Regular checkpoints to track progress and adapt goals
Clear deadlines encourage focused effort within each sprint
Fewer opportunities to deliver working software

mcqs.question_text: Which statements describe the Product Backlog Items (PBIs)? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: They can represent features, user stories, technical work, or improvements
They are fixed for the entire project once written
They are sorted by priority or business value
They never require refinement or re-estimation

mcqs.question_text: Which two metrics are often used to estimate PBIs, as mentioned in the lecture? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: Effort required in hours/days
The number of developers on the team
Story points representing relative complexity
Times the code has been committed

mcqs.question_text: Which activities typically happen during a Sprint Review? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: Stakeholders inspect the Increment and provide feedback
Team finalizes backlog items for the next 12 months
Team demonstrates completed PBIs meeting the Definition of Done
All future sprints are canceled if any item is incomplete

mcqs.question_text: What is the primary goal of the Sprint Retrospective?

options.option_text: To discuss code structure in detail with the Product Owner
To review and adjust processes for continuous improvement
To finalize the product for immediate deployment
To estimate velocity for the next four sprints

mcqs.question_text: Which statement about the Definition of Done is true?

options.option_text: It ensures that each increment meets agreed quality standards before calling it complete
It is defined by external auditors with no input from the team
It only applies to Waterfall projects
It does not need to include testing requirements

mcqs.question_text: Which statements accurately describe cross-functional Scrum Teams? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: They include all necessary skills to create a working increment (e.g., coding, testing, UX) within the team
They rely solely on external teams for design and testing
They can deliver end-to-end features each sprint
They do not communicate with stakeholders until the product is shipped

mcqs.question_text: Which principle supports letting the Developers self-organize how they accomplish Sprint Goals?

options.option_text: Empiricism via Inspection
Self-Management or Self-Organization
Command-and-Control Management
Waterfall's sequential approach

mcqs.question_text: When are PBIs typically refined or re-estimated in Scrum?

options.option_text: During regular backlog refinement sessions or as new information emerges
Only after the final product increment is shipped
Never, since initial estimates must remain fixed
At the daily scrum, by the Product Owner alone

mcqs.question_text: Which of the following is a key element of the Code Completeness Checklist mentioned in the lecture?

options.option_text: Ensuring code is reviewed and passes all required tests before an item can be called Done
Releasing code immediately to production without tests
Submitting incomplete code to the Product Owner for acceptance
Focusing on integration tests only and ignoring unit tests

mcqs.question_text: Which statements are true about team composition tips mentioned in the lecture? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: Teams of ≤ 8 members are generally recommended for efficiency
A single team member must handle all external interactions permanently
Self-organization fosters flexibility in distributing tasks among available skills
Teams should never adapt their roles or responsibilities over time

mcqs.question_text: What do the Empiricism Pillars (Transparency, Inspection, Adaptation) encourage in Scrum?

options.option_text: They ensure processes are visible, validated regularly, and adjusted based on learnings
They demand fixed, unchangeable requirements once the sprint starts
They require detailed Gantt charts for each sprint milestone
They replace the need for a Product Owner and ScrumMaster

mcqs.question_text: Which of the following might you find in a Product Backlog? (3 correct options)

options.option_text: Features requested by users for future sprints
Large-scale refactoring tasks or technical spikes
The daily tasks each developer must do tomorrow
Bugs reported that need to be fixed in a future sprint
Final acceptance testing only after project completion

mcqs.question_text: Which statement best describes the role of the 'Sprint Backlog'?

options.option_text: It is the set of Product Backlog items the team commits to delivering during a Sprint
It is a backlog of leftover tasks from previous Sprints that nobody wants to do
It is a list of blocked items that can’t be done for at least six months
It is the official capacity plan for all future releases

mcqs.question_text: Which statement correctly distinguishes Sprint Review from Sprint Retrospective?

options.option_text: The Review focuses on what was delivered and gathering feedback; the Retrospective focuses on how the team worked and improving processes
The Review is optional, but the Retrospective is mandatory
Both events are dedicated solely to design discussions
The Retrospective is the only place where stakeholders can see the Increment

mcqs.question_text: Which statement accurately reflects how the ScrumMaster might handle project management responsibilities?

options.option_text: They adapt as needed, guiding the team and bridging external interactions without top-down control
They fully replace the Product Owner in writing backlog items
They serve primarily as a technical lead who reviews all code changes
They own the final release decisions and can override the team’s Sprint commitment

mcqs.question_text: Which of the following is a well-formed example of a Product Backlog Item (PBI)? (1 correct option)

options.option_text: "As a user, I want to reset my password via email link, so that I can securely access my account." (Acceptance Criteria: Email link expires in 24 hours; user must confirm new password twice.)
"Implement the internal refactoring for all legacy modules, no acceptance criteria needed."
"Improve performance and security across all microservices, due next Sprint. No further details."
"Add the new feature when we have time, but skip testing if the Sprint is too short."

mcqs.question_text: Scenario: Mid-sprint, a high-priority feature request arises. The Product Owner wants to add it immediately, but the Developers are already focused on the Sprint Goal. How should the ScrumMaster respond? (1 correct option)

options.option_text: Facilitate a discussion to see if the new feature can replace or adjust existing Sprint Backlog items without jeopardizing the Sprint Goal
Automatically insert the new work without discussing with the team, since the Product Owner has final authority
Deny any changes during a Sprint under all circumstances
Cancel the Sprint immediately and start a new one to accommodate the request

mcqs.question_text: Scenario: The Product Owner suddenly informs the team of multiple urgent change requests at mid-sprint. The team has ongoing tasks that are halfway complete, and the Sprint Goal is at risk. Which actions should the ScrumMaster take? (2 correct options)

options.option_text: Encourage a discussion between the Product Owner and Developers to see if any lower-priority items can be traded off to maintain the Sprint Goal
Facilitate a short meeting to consider re-prioritizing the Sprint Backlog, ensuring the team’s agreement on any updates
Immediately replace all ongoing tasks with the new requests, skipping refinement or planning
Extend the Sprint length to accommodate the new requests without informing the stakeholders

true_false_questions.question_text: Scrum is an Agile methodology that relies on timeboxed iterations known as Sprints, each producing a potentially shippable Increment of the product.
The ScrumMaster is responsible for maximizing the product’s value and writing all PBIs.
Commitment, Focus, Openness, Respect, and Courage are core Scrum values.
A Product Backlog is a static list that cannot change once a project has started.
Sprint Planning aims to define a Sprint Goal and select Product Backlog Items to work on in the Sprint.
The Daily Scrum is a lengthy two-hour meeting where developers share detailed code walkthroughs.
Velocity is a measure of the team’s productivity—how much work they can accomplish in a Sprint.
The Sprint Backlog is owned by the Product Owner and can be changed at any time without consulting the developers.
Scrum’s pillars include Transparency, Inspection, and Adaptation, emphasizing empirical process control.
The Sprint Review includes demonstrating the increment to stakeholders and collecting feedback for the Product Backlog.
The Sprint Retrospective focuses on improving the upcoming Sprint by examining what went well and what could be better.
Scrum Teams must have at least 20 developers to function properly, according to the lecture.
Cross-functional teams in Scrum imply each member can handle every role, including Product Owner and ScrumMaster.
The code completeness checklist ensures that any item labeled 'Done' has passed code reviews, unit tests, integration tests, and acceptance tests as required.
In Scrum, smaller teams (≤ 8 members) with diverse skills are often recommended for efficiency, self-organization, and resilience.
